Okay let's work an example in R^3, similar to the one worked out in this video.   Say you have two independent vectors in R3. I'll call them V and W. These form a subspace because they form a plane that goes through the origin. Let's call this subspace A.   In set notation (or algebraically), this subspace can be defined as A = (cV + dW | c,d  are Real numbers)   Now let's suppose you have another vector Y that goes through the origin as well. This is a line. It is a subspace because any combination of that line will either fall on the same line or be 0. Let's call this subspace B. In set notation, this is B = (cY | c is a real number).   Now there are at least 1 way and at most 2 ways these two subspaces can intersect. If vector Y is independent from W and V, then subspace A intersect B = 0 (they both pass through the origin and this the Zero vector is their only common element). 0 is a subspace so we are good.   Now suppose line Y is not independent and is this some linear combination of vectors V and W. In that case Y is already in the same subspace A of V and W. That means that  (cY = dV + eW | c, d, e are real numbers). Thus subspace B of Y was really just a line in the plane of subspace A.

Great video,  but there is a big error. 6:13 "Do I have a subspace if I take all the vectors on the plane and all the ones on the line? No." False. In general you don't have a subspace, but it depends, sometimes you have one. The correct answer would be "If the plane contains the line yes, otherwise no", another correct answer would be "in general no".  But answering just "No" you are implicitly saying "Always no" which is false and incorrect.

You can, you get infinite solutions

Because they're not constrained enough. Go back to a lower dimensional example: 1 eq, 2 unknowns, for instance y + 4x + 3 = 0. There isn't a solution. However, all the values x and y satisfying y = -4x - 3 (which is a line, actually), could be solutions. You'd need a (linearly independent) second equation to disambiguate between all those points to have a unique solution
they prob dont care who he is

Because column 3 of matrix A is a linear combination of columns 1 and 2, which means that columns 1  and 2 are sufficient enough to create column 3. We can't really draw vectors in R^4 so it's not really a plane but think like this: If Matrix A would of been a 3x3 instead then that would of been EXACTLY a plane(plane in this case meaning an infinitely large plane in all directions) in R^3. The 3 columns are not linearly independent. So you can throw away column1 and still get the same info by taking the linear combination C3-C2 (which is = C1) for this matrix. Hence the column space is the same with 2 columns as with all 3 columns of this matrix. Thats my understanding, at least.

Say the columns map a plane in 3D space. All three column vectors combined together make that plane, but in reality only two vectors are needed to make that plane, not three, so one is a duplicate. One is a duplicate, because it can be created from a linear combination of other two vectors. If a vector exists in a matrix that can be created from the other vectors than it can be said that it depends on the other vectors, and if it's a unique vector that is not a combination of any other vectors in that matrix it's called an independent vector.

So this is my idea of a "vector subspace": It's an (N-1) dimensional slice of an N dimensional space, although it's only (N-1) dimensional in a certain sense of dimensionality size, because it has a sort of location information in N dimensions. So a vector space in R3 can be thought of a plane, a 2 dimensional object, relative to a 3 dimensional space. And the plane in this example must contain the origin of R3. ibrahimokdadov  well since we know that this matrix has when put it to RREF rank=2, that means that there are 2 independent column vectors, and they also form a basis for this colsp(A). But we also know that rank(A)=dimension of the column space. That is why is this a 2-D subspace. Note that if all 3 column vevtors were independent the rank(A)=dimension of colsp(A)=3. so the subspace would be 3-D.  Hope it helps.

Say you have a 3D space, well that space can contain a 2D object like a plane. So there can be a 2D space in a 3D space just like there can be a 2D object in a 4D space. And the reason is that some of the column vectors are duplicates. One or more of them can be created from a linear combination of two or more. So say, you have vectors ABC, for this example, A can be created from a combination of B and C, so B+C=A, so A is a duplicate vector here and will not add to the space. It will not add a dimension to this space. That means we are left with two vectors therefore leaving us in 2D space.

Zero is always a subspace, which being a point would be a zero dimensional slice of R^n. Also the whole R^n is a subspace of itself. So from 0 to n. In R^3: a point, a line, a plane and the whole 3d space are all possible subspaces.

No. Think of the vectors as points. Simply put, we have 3 points that will be in the subspace i.e. col1, col2 and [0 0 0 0]. These 3 points and their linear combinations can not go out of the plane that contains them. Having 3 unique points in some n dim space, you can only define a 2-D plane.

Thus authors of such texts VIOLATE their OWN rules in the early chapters of the text.  I understand why they do so, but they almost always do so somewhat high-handedly, with NO EXPLANATION of the pedagogical philosophy behind their ABUSE OF NOTATION.  Instructors who use this abused notation in class seem to be surprised that some students get confused by it.  These students are in some cases exactly the students who are being most attentive to detail, which is a necessary mathematical skill.

(In such texts, students also are told that that they MUST NOT say that a matrix A is equal to a matrix B when B does not have exactly the same number of columns as A.)  The use of the notation "R^3" for the space of real (3x1) matrices (aka (3x1) column vectors) requires one to accept a conflation of three DIFFERENT KINDS of real vectors with three entries, 3-tuples of real numbers, row vectors with exactly three real entries, and column vectors with exactly three real entries.  (2 B continued)

Professor Strang is an iconic figure in Linear Algebra, but in this video, he uses notation that violates one of my pet peaves:  R^3 for the space of (3x1) matrices with all real entries.  The trouble is that in essentially every linear algebra text at this level, the early introductory material includes very strong admonitions to students that they MUST NOT say that a matrix A is equal to a matrix B when B does not have exactly the same number of rows as A.  (To be continued...)

I love how he continues to pretend that he just makes up all his examples ad hoc while in the end it always turns out that he prepped all of it in advance. "Oh, what a great suprise that it worked out so well!!"

I guess you simply don't understand it or you don't know/forgot that all of this matrix stuff is an abstraction (or not even that, just a different notation) of solving systems of linear equations. Oh besides, linear algebra is often used to simplify functions in calculus.

That is correct. But it was asked whether the set of vectors in P and L together form a subspace. They do not because you can find vectors in P you can add to vectors of L, and the result vector is not in P and not in L. So P and L cannot form a subspace if L isn't a subspace of P.
Thanks I got it.

There are a lot of weird terms in Linear Algebra (like "Reduced Row Echelon Form" and "Gauss-Jordan Elimination", lmfao), however all of it is based on fairly simple ideas, they just tend to look weird and unintuitive when you get formulas and various shortcuts thrown at you. But you can pretty much always experiment around with the matrices and derive stuff to prove those things to yourself.  For example, a "determinant" might seem weird if you just follow the pattern "take the product of these numbers, then subtract the product of these numbers" etc etc etc, but really, a detereminant is just a possible pivot that has to be nonzero in order to create a pivot in every row. Try turning a 2x2 matrix into the Echelon form --- possibly with the constants a, b, c and d --- when you are more familiar with Linear Algebra and you will see that row 2, column 2 ends up as ad-bc, which is the determinant for that matrix.

The question he actually meant/wanted to ask is the one he asked at 26:00 which is essentially the same as the one you pointed out and would equal your second interpretation. Because if all columns are INdependent the subspace would be 3D (in R4) but if the 3e column would be Dependent the subspace would be 2D (in R4) and the 3e column would just be a variation (linear combination) of the 1e and 2e columns. By the way, the only 4D subspace in R4 possible is R4 itself.

@SynthMelody Maybe a simpler example helps. We take the X axis as one subspace and the Y axis as another subspace. So the union of those two spaces is all vectors on either axis, but nowhere else. For example (1 0 0) is on the X axis and (0 1 0) is on the Y axis. But the sum of the (1 1 0) is not on either of those lines. It's outside of it, so the union can't be a subspace, as otherwise you'd stay inside it when you add two vectors.

@SynthMelody The union is not a subspace. The union is bigger than P or L so it definitely can't be a subspace of either of them. and by adding a vector from P with a vector from U you can get to a point that is neither in P nor in U or in other words by adding two points from P∪L you can get to points outside of P∪L (somewhere in R³). But to form a subspace you have to be able to add any vectors from that subspace and the result has to be in that subspace.

HELP! I think Strang might have got WRONG around 05:40. I think P U L is a SUBSPACE of P as P & L itself is a subspace of P.  Think like this: let p & l be a vector from P & L respectively. than u=p+l belongs to P U L and u lies within P as p is within P and l is also within P.  Also c*p & c*l belongs to P & L respectively where c is scalar as P&L are subspace. so c*u=(c*p + c*l) belongs to P U L.   Finally, zero vector lies in both P & L. so Zero vectors belongs to P U L. So P U L is subspace.

"A subspace is closed under the operations of the vector space it is in. In this case, if you add two vectors in the space, it's sum must be in it. So if you take any vector in the space, and add it's negative, it's sum is the zero vector, which is then by definition in the subspace."
